problem_text:
2.78.
Any set of all subgroups of the same given order of a finite group G that
contains at least one non-normal subgroup is called an IE¯n-system of G. A positive
integer k is called a soluble (non-soluble; simple; composite; absolutely simple)
group-theoretic number if every finite group having exactly k IE¯n-systems is soluble
(respectively, if there is at least one non-soluble finite group having k IE¯n-systems;
if there is at least one simple finite group having k IE¯n-systems; if there are no
simple finite groups having k IE¯n-systems; if there is at least one simple finite group
having k IE¯n-systems and there are no non-soluble non-simple finite groups having
k IE¯n-systems).
Are the sets of all soluble and of all absolutely simple group-theoretic numbers
finite or infinite? Do there exist composite, but not soluble group-theoretic numbers?
P. I. Trofimov
